item.title: Leader of Russian Mercenary Group Affirms Ukraine’s Hold on Bakhmut
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin had previously asserted that his forces had or were near taking control of the city in eastern Ukraine, the focus of one of Russia’s longest-running assaults. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A man collecting metal in his yard after it was destroyed in combat, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Strikes Lebanon After Rocket Attack From Militias
item.description: The Israeli military blamed Palestinian exiles in Lebanon for what appeared to be a retaliatory attack over Israel’s raid of a mosque at a Jerusalem holy site two days earlier.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: An explosion in Gaza City caused by an Israeli airstrike on Friday.

item.title: Xi and Macron Call for Ukraine Peace Talks, but the Path Is Murky
item.description: It is not clear that the Chinese and French leaders — much less Russia and Ukraine — have compatible terms for talks or peace, and Mr. Xi has not publicly agreed to pressure Moscow to negotiate.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, right, and France’s President Emmanuel Macron at a welcome ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, on Thursday.

item.title: Indian Textbooks Purged of Material Modi’s Party Finds Objectionable
item.description: The changes removed or shrank references to material that the governing party of Prime Minister Narendra Modi finds inconvenient to its Hindu-first vision.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Students looking through textbooks at a public primary school in Hyderabad, India, last year.

item.title: In Northern Ireland, Painful Memories Lie Beneath Good Friday Peace Accord
item.description: Twenty-five years after the Good Friday Agreement ended an era of bloodshed, this is a moment to celebrate reconciliation across Northern Ireland. But for many, the past is not always easy to leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in central Omagh in March. In 1998, the Northern Ireland town suffered the deadliest bombing of the era of violence known as the Troubles.

item.title: China Condemns Taiwan and U.S. Meeting in California
item.description: For Beijing, showing displeasure too openly carries risks, particularly of harming the chances for its preferred party in Taiwan’s coming presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a restaurant in Hualien, Taiwan, on Thursday, a TV news show features U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and Taiwan’s President Tsai Ing-wen, who met in California.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi, Former Italian Prime Minister, Is Being Treated for Leukemia
item.description: Mr. Berlusconi, who is in the intensive care unit at a Milan hospital, has had the blood disorder for “some time,” his personal physician said.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, former prime minister of Italy and leader of the party Forza Italia, at a campaign rally in Rome in September.

item.title: French Unions, Still Furious Over Pension Law, Resume Protests
item.description: Hundreds of thousands again took to the streets to rally against raising the retirement age, but there were signs that the demonstrations were losing some steam, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Demonstrators, some holding a sign calling for President Emmanuel Macron’s pension overhaul to be blocked, protesting in Nantes, western France, on Thursday.

item.title: Five Men Killed and Fears Over a Military’s Growing Power
item.description: Uniformed soldiers shot unarmed civilians then blocked medics from providing care, a top government official said. To many Mexicans, such abuse is all too familiar.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Galia García Palafox and Alejandro Cegarra
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of the army on patrol last year in Celaya, Mexico.

item.title: Nord Stream Whodunit Deepens as Shreds of Evidence Emerge
item.description: Intelligence leaks surrounding the sabotage of the pipelines have provided more questions than answers. It may be in no one’s interest to reveal more.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Danish Defense Command, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Danish Defense Command showing a gas leak from the Nord Stream 2 pipeline in the Baltic Sea in September.

item.title: U.K. Seafood Exports Race Against the Tides of Brexit
item.description: British seafood is prized in France and Spain far more than at home. Britain’s exit from the European Union hasn’t halted exports, but the path from sea to stovetop is fraught with new obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa

item.title: ‘Joyland,’ an L.G.B.T. Pakistani Film, Is Celebrated Abroad
item.description: Saim Sadiq’s feature “Joyland,” which includes a transgender woman’s love affair, cannot be shown in Pakistan’s Punjab Province.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times

item.title: How AI and DNA Are Unlocking the Mysteries of Global Supply Chains
item.description: Firms are turning to advanced technologies to help answer a surprisingly tricky question: Where do products really come from?
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cotton being tested at Applied DNA Sciences in New York to trace its origins.

item.title: Dmitry Krymov, Exiled Russian Director, Starts Over in New York
item.description: Dmitry Krymov, one of Russia’s most eminent directors, is among the dozens of artists who have left their homeland since Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Jeremy Fassler
item.category: The Square Root of Three Sisters (Play)
item.media:description: Dmitry Krymov, one of Russia’s most important theater directors, has remained in the United States since signing a letter opposing Russia’s war in Ukraine.

item.title: Who Jacinda Ardern Really Is
item.description: As told in her first and farewell speeches.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mark Mitchell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern, the former prime minister of New Zealand, wearing a traditional Maori cloak during her final speech to Parliament.

item.title: Baptist Minister in Myanmar Gets 6 Years in Prison for Opposing Junta
item.description: The minister met with President Donald J. Trump in 2019 to highlight the abuses of Myanmar’s military, which later seized power in a coup.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hkalam Samson, right, the former head of the Kachin Baptist Convention, talking to a member of his congregation after a Sunday service in Myitkyina, Myanmar, in 2013.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A war documents leak.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Leaked documents do not provide specific battle plans, but they offer a snapshot of what Ukrainian troops might need for the campaign.

item.title: Ukraine War Plans Leak Prompts Pentagon Investigation
item.description: Classified documents detailing secret American and NATO plans have appeared on Twitter and Telegram.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The leaked documents do not provide specific battle plans but they offer a snapshot of time — the American and Ukrainian view, as of March 1, of what Ukrainian troops might need for the campaign.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Meets With Russian Official on Evan Gershkovich Detention
item.description: Lynne M. Tracy, the ambassador, spoke with Sergei A. Ryabkov, the Russian deputy foreign minister. U.S. officials have not been granted consular access to Mr. Gershkovich in the past week, a State Department official said.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, was escorted from the Lefortovsky court in Moscow to a bus last week.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. Admits Flaws in Afghanistan Withdrawal
item.description: Plus China and France call for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine, and India scrubs its textbooks.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghans trying to flee the country waved their documents at U.S. Marines outside the Kabul airport in August 2021.

item.title: Marlène Schiappa Posed for Playboy (Clothed). France Is Looking, and Talking.
item.description: Critics have questioned the junior minister’s choice of publication, and called the magazine shoot a distraction amid nationwide protests over a new pension law.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: The French cabinet minister Marlène Schiappa has been embroiled in a controversy over her French Playboy cover.

item.title: Zelensky’s Aides Send Mixed Messages on Crimea
item.description: Top government officials in Kyiv clarify that their mission remains to reclaim all Ukrainian territory from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian troops at a Ukrainian military compound in Crimea in 2014. Russia’s illegal annexation of the peninsula that year was a precursor to its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

item.title: NATO Countries Are Divided Over Giving Ukraine Membership, Officials Say
item.description: The debate on the status of Kyiv will continue up to the military alliance’s mid-July summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, during a meeting of the alliance’s foreign ministers in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Acknowledges Afghanistan Evacuation Should Have Started Sooner
item.description: President Biden’s decision to end a 20-year war in August 2021 led to the swift collapse of the Afghan government and military. His administration has placed heavy blame on his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghans trying to flee the country waved their documents at U.S. Marines outside the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August 2021.

item.title: Biden Administration to Curb Toxic Pollutants From Chemical Plants
item.description: The rule would chiefly affect plants along the Gulf Coast, the Ohio River Valley and in West Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A chemical plant owned by the Japanese company Denka, known to emit the carcinogenic chemical chloroprene, in Reserve, La.

item.title: Prigozhin, Russia’s Wagner Leader, Says Ukraine Continues to Fight in Bakhmut
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, who leads the mercenary group, also said that Russia would need better organization and more ammunition to push beyond the besieged city.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers running between frontline positions in Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Saudi and Iranian Foreign Ministers Meet in China After Thaw
item.description: The high-level talks were a sign that the regional rivals were moving ahead with an agreement to re-establish relations, mediated last month by Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Iranian Foreign Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Saudi foreign minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan, left, met with his Iranian counterpart, Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, on Thursday in Beijing.

item.title: The Power and Limits of Abortion Politics
item.description: What should we make of the role that abortion played in both the Chicago and Wisconsin elections this week?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Evan Cobb for The New York Times, Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brandon Johnson and Janet Protasiewicz.

item.title: Man Accused of Kidnapping Platypus Is Charged in Australia
item.description: The police had appealed for help after the platypus was spotted at a train station in Queensland. The animal was later released, but the authorities have been unable to find it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Queensland Police Service/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Images from the Queensland Police Service show a man who was spotted carrying a wild platypus at a train station near Brisbane, Australia, this week.

item.title: In Alaska, ConocoPhillips Prepares for Willow Drilling Project
item.description: Scientists say nations must stop new oil and gas projects to avoid climate catastrophe. But after the Biden administration greenlit the $8 billion Willow project, ConocoPhillips is racing ahead.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Clifford Krauss and Erin Schaff

item.title: It’s Not Just Willow: Oil and Gas Projects Are Back in a Big Way
item.description: Alaska’s controversial Willow project has drawn criticism, but a global analysis shows that it’s just one of hundreds of investments approved in the past year or so.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: A refinery in Doha, Qatar. The country is planning to unveil the world’s biggest gas production facility in 2025.

item.title: 2 Generals Took Over Sudan. Will They Deliver Democracy or War?
item.description: The deadline is approaching for the generals who took power in a military coup in Sudan to turn over their authority to a civilian government. The mood in the capital, Khartoum, is anxious.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Faiz Abubakar Muhammed for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in Omdurman, the neighboring city across the Nile from Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, in March.

item.title: Macron’s meeting with Xi could affect the direction of the war.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France delivered a speech in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The reaction to criminal charges against Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump gave remarks at Mar-a-Lago after being arraigned in New York.

item.title: Keeping an Old Italian Tradition Alive in Australia: ‘Passata Day’
item.description: Two sisters are among the dwindling few who gather family and friends once a year to make a 12-month supply of tomato passata, a purée that is a staple of Italian cuisine.
item.dc:creator: Peter Di Sisto
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family and friends making tomato passata at Silvana Hurst’s house in Donvale, Australia.

item.title: Russia Accused of Spreading Disinformation at U.N. Security Council
item.description: Moscow used its rotating presidency of the Security Council to host a session on deported Ukrainian children, leading some officials to walk out.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Maria Lvova-Belova, head of Russia’s children’s protection agency, addressed the U.N. Security Council via video on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky Gets Hero’s Welcome in Poland, Cementing Ukraine’s Ties
item.description: Polish leaders backed Ukraine’s bid for NATO membership, but even without that, Russia’s invasion is making the alliance’s eastern flank more united, and more important.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking in the courtyard of the Royal Castle in Warsaw on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin and Lukashenko to Discuss Deepening Ties Between Russia and Belarus
item.description: The leader of Belarus is in Russia for talks on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus embracing at the Kremlin on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Diplomatic Visits Highlight Tension With China
item.description: Also, what’s next for Donald Trump and Israeli police raid a Jerusalem mosque.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwanese President, meets with Kevin McCarthy, Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, at the Ronald Regan Presidential Library on Wednesday.

item.title: Italian Ex-Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi Is Hospitalized
item.description: The 86-year-old businessman-turned-politician, now a senator, was admitted to an intensive care unit in Milan. He was said to have a “problem related to a previous infection.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: San Raffaele Hospital in Milan. The former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was admitted on Wednesday and is expected to stay for a few days.

item.title: Macron, in China, Says He’ll Urge Xi to Work for Peace in Ukraine
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke of the need for a “shared responsibility for peace and international stability.”
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Beijing, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden’s Ambassador to Israel, at the Center of the Storm
item.description: A longtime Democratic insider, Thomas Nides navigates a fraught U.S.-Israel relationship with humor, if a sometimes all-too-quotable candor.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Thomas R. Nides, the U.S. ambassador to Israel, is President Biden’s main conduit for what are frequently unwelcome messages to Israel’s prime minister and his top lieutenants.

item.title: U.S. Tensions With China on Display as McCarthy Hosts Taiwan’s Leader
item.description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy became the most senior elected official to meet with a Taiwanese president on American soil since the United States established diplomatic relations with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy met with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library on Wednesday.

item.title: Tunisia’s Influence in Europe
item.description: The European Union relies heavily on Tunisia to stem migration, giving its increasingly authoritarian president leverage in negotiations with the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Kais Saied, seen here on a poster in Kairouan, has derailed Tunisia’s infant democracy.

item.title: E.P.A. to Tighten Limits on Mercury and Other Pollutants From Power Plants
item.description: A new rule would reduce mercury, arsenic, nickel and lead emissions, which the Biden administration said would protect public health.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal power plant in Colver, Pa. The new rule aims to eliminate 70 percent of remaining mercury emissions, as well as reduce other toxic pollutants like lead, nickel and arsenic.

item.title: John Joseph Went to Australia for Gold, Then Stood Up for Democracy
item.description: John Joseph was put on trial for leading a miners’ rebellion seeking less taxation and more representation. His legacy was forgotten — until now.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caroline Kennedy, the United States ambassador to Australia, unveiling a plaque remembering Mr. Joseph at White Hills Cemetery last month.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon’s Husband Arrested as Scottish Party Is Investigated
item.description: Peter Murrell, a longtime Scottish National Party official, was detained by the police for about 11 hours over the handling of donations raised to campaign for a second independence vote.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: What We Learned From Trump’s Arraignment
item.description: The case against him is about more than Stormy Daniels.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.category: New York State Criminal Case Against Trump (71543-23)
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump at the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building yesterday.

item.title: Polish Leaders Hope Defense of a Dead Pope Propels Them to Re-election
item.description: Criticism of John Paul II, the canonized, Polish-born pope who is a national hero, has fueled anger that the governing party wants to turn into votes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A picture of Pope John Paul II was displayed on the facade of the Presidential Palace in Warsaw, Poland, in March.

item.title: How a Tiny Literary Magazine Became a Springboard for Great Irish Writing
item.description: The Stinging Fly has helped launch several of Ireland’s most promising writers. How has a publication with 1,000 subscribers carved a niche in the Irish canon?
item.dc:creator: Max Ufberg
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Declan Meade, a founding editor of The Stinging Fly, wanted to create a home for “all this great writing floating around.” In its 25 years, magazine has become a source of community and a launchpad for Irish writers.

item.title: ‘If I Stop Now I’ll Have Nothing’: The African Students Who Fled Ukraine
item.description: One student, accepted at a Georgian school, had her visa application rejected. Another, 18 months from his medical degree, received a deportation order from Germany. “It just makes you want to stop in the street and scream,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohamed Elfatih Ahmed in Hamburg, Germany.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern’s Career in New Zealand Politics Ends
item.description: The former prime minister, who is now stepping down from Parliament, urged lawmakers to take action on climate change.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern giving her last speech in New Zealand’s Parliament, in Wellington, on Wednesday.

item.title: China faces pressure to rein in Russia, but may have limited sway.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a visit in Moscow last month.

item.title: Israeli Police Raid Jerusalem Mosque; Brief Flare-Up With Gaza Follows
item.description: The raid at the sensitive holy site set off Palestinian rocket fire from the Gaza Strip, followed by Israeli airstrikes on the territory. On Wednesday night, there was a second raid at the compound.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Patrick Kingsley
